title: 美國人不愛儲蓄 39％掏不出400美元應急

replies.msg:
2019-05-24 12:16
〔即時新聞／綜合報導〕美國聯邦儲備委員會昨（23日）公佈美國家庭經濟福利報告，發現若遇到要多花400美元（約新台幣1.2萬元）的意外狀況時，只有61％的美國人能用現金、存款或信用卡支付，不過這樣已經不錯了，畢竟比去年的比率略有改善。

據《福斯新聞》報導，在39％無法馬上拿錢支付400美元的民眾中，有超過25％的人必須賣掉東西才能付錢，而有12％的人完全無法負擔這筆費用。

這代表假如遇到相對來說較小的意外開支，例如汽車維修或更換破損的家電設備，對於沒有足夠儲蓄的家庭來說可能相當困難。

儘管美國經濟增強、失業率處於近半個世紀以來的低點，人們仍然不愛儲蓄，不過有75％的美國民眾認為自身的財務狀況已讓自己過得很不錯了。

https://news.ltn.com.tw/news/world/breakingnews/2800566

replies.msg:
Bloomberg

Almost 40% of Americans Would Struggle to Cover a $400 Emergency
By Matthew Boesler

2019年5月24日 GMT+8 上午12:13

Many U.S. households find themselves in a fragile position financially, even in an economy with an unemployment rate near a 50-year low, according to a Federal Reserve survey.

The Fed’s 2018 report on the economic well-being of households, published Thursday, indicated “most measures” of well-being and financial resilience “were similar to, or slightly better than, those in 2017.” The slight improvement coincided with a decline in the average unemployment rate to 3.9% last year, from 4.3% in 2017.

But despite the advance, the results of the 2018 survey indicated that almost 40% of Americans would still struggle in the face of a $400 financial emergency. The statistic, which was a bit better than in the 2017 report, has become a favorite rejoinder to U.S. President Donald Trump’s boasts about a strong economy among Democratic politicians, including 2020 presidential candidate Kamala Harris, the U.S. senator from California.

https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-05-23/almost-40-of-americans-would-struggle-to-cover-a-400-emergency

美國聯邦儲備委員會

Overall, the financial experiences reported by the 11,000 adults surveyed in 2018 were largely positive, and many families have experienced substantial gains since the survey began in 2013, in line with the nation's ongoing economic expansion. When asked about their overall economic well-being, 75 percent of U.S. adults said they were "doing okay" or "living comfortably"—up 12 percentage points from 2013. The survey also asked how they would pay for a hypothetical unexpected expense of $400. Sixty-one percent said they would pay the expense with cash, savings, or a credit card paid off at the next statement; 27 percent would borrow or sell something; and 12 percent would not be able to cover it. In 2013, only half of adults said they would pay with cash or its equivalent.

https://www.federalreserve.gov/newsevents/pressreleases/other20190523b.htm
